ctrlnmod.lmis package

Submodules

ctrlnmod.lmis.base module

class ctrlnmod.lmis.base.LMI(module, extract_matrices)[source]

Bases: ABC, Module

Base class for all Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMI). An LMI is built from the weights of a PyTorch Module. Subclasses must implement the specific attributes/submatrices they need to compute the forward method.

Parameters:

  • module (Module)

  • extract_matrices (Callable)

check_(tol=1e-09)[source]

Checks if the matrix is positive semidefinite within a user-defined tolerance.

Parameters:

tol (float) – The tolerance for checking positive semidefiniteness.

Returns:

True if the matrix is positive semidefinite within the given tolerance, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

forward()[source]

Returns M as a positive definite matrix.

Returns:

A positive definite matrix.

Return type:

Tensor

classmethod solve(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Returns the LMI and the corresponding bounds and certificates for evaluation.

Parameters:

  • tensors (Tuple[Tensor]) – A tuple of tensors required for solving the LMI.

  • solver (str) – The solver to be used for LMI.

  • tol (float) – The tolerance for the solver.

Returns:

The solution of the LMI and the corresponding bounds.

Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

ctrlnmod.lmis.h2 module

class ctrlnmod.lmis.h2.H2Cont(A, B, C, gamma2=None, P=None)[source]

Bases: LMI

This LMI gives an upper bound on the H2 norm of continiuous-time linear system.

\* A

state transition matrix

Type:

Tensor

\* B

input matrix

Type:

Tensor

\* C

output matrix

Type:

Tensor

\* gamma2

upper bound on L2 gain

\* P

Lyapunov certificate

solve : classmethod

solve the LMI for given (A,B,C) triplet

Raises:

ValueError : – if the SDP problem problem is infeasible or unbounded

Parameters:

  • A (Tensor)

  • B (Tensor)

  • C (Tensor)

  • gamma2 (Tensor | None)

  • P (Tensor | None)

forward()[source]

This not the true H2 just Lyapunov equation. Enforcing it to be equal to BB^T is not possible via logdet.

classmethod solve(A, B, C, solver='MOSEK', epsilon=1e-05)[source]

Returns the LMI and the corresponding bounds and certificates for evaluation.

Parameters:

  • tensors (Tuple[Tensor]) – A tuple of tensors required for solving the LMI.

  • solver (str) – The solver to be used for LMI.

  • tol (float) – The tolerance for the solver.

  • A (Tensor)

  • B (Tensor)

  • C (Tensor)

Returns:

The solution of the LMI and the corresponding bounds.

Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

ctrlnmod.lmis.lipschitz module

class ctrlnmod.lmis.lipschitz.Lipschitz(module, extract_matrices, beta=1.0, epsilon=1e-06, solver='MOSEK')[source]

Bases: LMI

This class computes an upper bound on the Lipschitz constant for a neural network that can be put into a standard form like

..math:

z = Az + Bx w = Sigma(z) y = Cw

with :math: Sigma being a diagonal operator collecting all activation functions. It is assumed the activation functions in \(Sigma\) are slope restricted in \([0, \beta]\).

Notethis an algebraic equation, so for this form to be well-posed,

a sufficient condition can be that A strictly lower triangular but other conditions exist. See for example https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.05942

Parameters:

  • module (Module)

  • extract_matrices (Callable[[], Tuple[Tensor, ...]])

  • beta (float)

  • epsilon (float)

  • solver (str)

A

the interconnexion matrix of size (nz x nz)

Type:

Tensor

B

the input matrix of size (nz x n_in)

Type:

Tensor

C

the output matrix of size (n_out x nz)

Type:

Tensor

extract_matrices

a method provided by the model to extract the submatrices for LMI

Type:

Callable

beta

maximum admitted slope for activation functions Default = 1

Type:

float

lip

lipschitz constant for the network

Type:

float

Lambda_vec

1-D vector representing the diagonal matrix certificate for LMI feasibility

Type:

Tensor

ExtractMatricesFn

alias of Callable[[], Tuple[Tensor, …]]

forward()[source]

Returns M as a positive definite matrix.

Returns:

A positive definite matrix.

Return type:

Tensor

Parameters:

  • B (Tensor | None)

  • C (Tensor | None)

  • solver (str)

classmethod solve(A, B, C, beta=1, solver='MOSEK', tol=1e-08)[source]
Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, Tensor, Tensor]

This class computes an upper bound on the Lipschitz constant for a neural network that can be put into a standard form like

Parameters:

  • A (Tensor)

  • B (Tensor)

  • C (Tensor)

  • beta (float)

  • solver (str)

  • tol (float)

..math:

z = Az + Bx w = Sigma(z) y = Cw

with :math: Sigma being a diagonal operator collecting all activation functions. It is assumed the activation functions in \(Sigma\) are slope restricted in \([0, \beta]\).

Notethis an algebraic equation, so for this form to be well-posed,

a sufficient condition can be that A strictly lower triangular but other conditions exist. See for example https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.05942 or

https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.02929

TODO : for bigger networks solving the LMI is actually difficult for LBDN architecture have to check why !

classmethod solve(A, alpha, tol=1e-09, solver='MOSEK', Q=None)[source]

Solve the continuous-time Lyapunov LMI using cvxpy.

Parameters:

  • A (Tensor) – The system matrix A.

  • alpha (float) – The decay rate alpha for alpha-stability.

  • tol (float) – The tolerance for the solver.

  • solver (str) – The solver to use for cvxpy.

Returns:

The positive definite solution matrix P and the corresponding bounds.

Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

class ctrlnmod.lmis.LMI(module, extract_matrices)[source]

Bases: ABC, Module

Base class for all Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMI). An LMI is built from the weights of a PyTorch Module. Subclasses must implement the specific attributes/submatrices they need to compute the forward method.

Parameters:

  • module (Module)

  • extract_matrices (Callable)

check_(tol=1e-09)[source]

Checks if the matrix is positive semidefinite within a user-defined tolerance.

Parameters:

tol (float) – The tolerance for checking positive semidefiniteness.

Returns:

True if the matrix is positive semidefinite within the given tolerance, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

class ctrlnmod.lmis.Lipschitz(module, extract_matrices, beta=1.0, epsilon=1e-06, solver='MOSEK')[source]

Bases: LMI

This class computes an upper bound on the Lipschitz constant for a neural network that can be put into a standard form like

..math:

z = Az + Bx w = Sigma(z) y = Cw

with :math: Sigma being a diagonal operator collecting all activation functions. It is assumed the activation functions in \(Sigma\) are slope restricted in \([0, \beta]\).

Notethis an algebraic equation, so for this form to be well-posed,

a sufficient condition can be that A strictly lower triangular but other conditions exist. See for example https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.05942

Parameters:

  • module (Module)

  • extract_matrices (Callable[[], Tuple[Tensor, ...]])

  • beta (float)

  • epsilon (float)

  • solver (str)

A

the interconnexion matrix of size (nz x nz)

Type:

Tensor

B

the input matrix of size (nz x n_in)

Type:

Tensor

C

the output matrix of size (n_out x nz)

Type:

Tensor

extract_matrices

a method provided by the model to extract the submatrices for LMI

Type:

Callable

beta

maximum admitted slope for activation functions Default = 1

Type:

float

lip

lipschitz constant for the network

Type:

float

Lambda_vec

1-D vector representing the diagonal matrix certificate for LMI feasibility

Type:

Tensor
